docs.snippet: The social network, which hopes video will become an increasingly part of its business, said it would limit ads from appearing on unsuitable content.

headline.print_headline: Feeling Heat From Top Brands, Facebook Blocks Ads From Noxious Content
headline.main: Facebook Moves to Keep Ads From Running on Objectionable Videos

docs.snippet: We’re bringing together a group of our most dedicated readers to talk about our coverage and connect with our journalists and other Times readers.

headline.print_headline: Nominate Yourself to Be Part of Our Reader Center Facebook Community
headline.main: Nominate Yourself to Be Part of Our Reader Center Facebook Community

docs.snippet: The Russia-linked ads used to influence the 2016 election included those from a fake gun-rights group, a bogus gay rights group and even a phony dog lovers group.

headline.print_headline: Russian Facebook Ads Masked Themselves in Gun Rights, Rainbows and Puppies
headline.main: Facebook’s Russia-Linked Ads Came in Many Disguises

docs.snippet: Facebook, Google and Twitter disclosed more about Russian agents’ use of their platforms in the 2016 election as they prepare for hearings before Congress.

headline.print_headline: Broad Reach Of Campaign By Russians Is Disclosed
headline.main: Russian Influence Reached 126 Million Through Facebook Alone

docs.snippet: The social network’s board withdrew a stock reclassification proposal after a shareholder suit that would have put Mr. Zuckerberg in a courtroom.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Drops Stock Move That Would Have Solidified Zuckerberg’s Control
headline.main: Facebook Drops Stock Move That Would Have Solidified Zuckerberg’s Control

docs.snippet: Sheryl Sandberg’s meeting on Thursday with the Congressional Black Caucus afforded lawmakers a chance to vent over Russia’s exploitation of racial division.

headline.print_headline: Black Lawmakers Vent About Russia’s Meddling, And Facebook’s Response
headline.main: Black Lawmakers Hold a Particular Grievance With Facebook: Racial Exploitation

docs.snippet: The page, posing as an activist group, was one of hundreds of fake accounts Russia used in an information campaign during the election, a revelation that has put Facebook on the defensive.

headline.print_headline: Fake Facebook Account With Ties to the Kremlin Posed as U.S. Activists
headline.main: Purged Facebook Page Tied to the Kremlin Spread Anti-Immigrant Bile

docs.snippet: Sheryl Sandberg went on a public relations offensive with lawmakers as investigations into Russian interference in the presidential election continued.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Goes to Washington: DealBook Briefing
headline.main: Facebook Goes to Washington: DealBook Briefing

docs.snippet: Mr. Zuckerberg’s modus operandi as a leader is to fix things long after they have broken, rather than to prevent problems in the first place.

headline.print_headline: On Russian Ads, Facebook Chief  Draws From a Familiar Playbook
headline.main: On Russian Meddling, Mark Zuckerberg Follows a Familiar Playbook

docs.snippet: At Advertising Week, the social network extolled its size and reach to marketers, even while facing criticism over the misuse of its ad-targeting tools.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Pitches Size and Reach, Despite Concern Over How Tools Are Used
headline.main: Amid Facebook’s Troubles, Message to Advertisers Stays Consistent
